content: But ruling also allows existing same-sex unions to stand SAN FRANCISCO - California's highest court on Tuesday upheld the state's gay-marriage ban but allowed existing same-sex marriages to stand. The California Supreme Court handed down its decision in a series of lawsuits seeking to overturn November's Proposition 8. Gay-rights advocates maintain the ballot measure so dramatically revised the state constitution's equal protection clause that it needed the Legislature's approval before it could be put to voters. The seven-member court upheld the initiative as a constitutional expression of the electorate's will, but also decided to sustain the marriages of an estimated 18,000 gay couples who wed before the measure passed with 52 percent of the vote. More at>>> >>>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30936298/

content: What this means is that any majority has the right to vote against any minority. People's civil rights and freedoms are defined by the majority now. What happens if other majorities believe they have the right to vote against the freedoms of any group they don't happen to like? Our system has checks and balances in place because majority is NOT supposed to overrule the rights of any minority. That's what we call tyranny. And in this case, the "majority" was a mere 2%. That's not a mandate or an overwhelming majority. They squeaked by with this, just narrowly, and are now dancing in glee that they were able to impose their religious beliefs on others.

content: But ruling also allows existing same-sex unions to stand SAN FRANCISCO - California's highest court on Tuesday upheld the state's gay-marriage ban but allowed existing same-sex marriages to stand. The California Supreme Court handed down its decision in a series of lawsuits seeking to overturn November's Proposition 8. Gay-rights advocates maintain the ballot measure so dramatically revised the state constitution's equal protection clause that it needed the Legislature's approval before it could be put to voters. The seven-member court upheld the initiative as a constitutional expression of the electorate's will, but also decided to sustain the marriages of an estimated 18,000 gay couples who wed before the measure passed with 52 percent of the vote. More at>>> >>>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30936298/

content: But ruling also allows existing same-sex unions to stand SAN FRANCISCO - California's highest court on Tuesday upheld the state's gay-marriage ban but allowed existing same-sex marriages to stand. The California Supreme Court handed down its decision in a series of lawsuits seeking to overturn November's Proposition 8. Gay-rights advocates maintain the ballot measure so dramatically revised the state constitution's equal protection clause that it needed the Legislature's approval before it could be put to voters. The seven-member court upheld the initiative as a constitutional expression of the electorate's will, but also decided to sustain the marriages of an estimated 18,000 gay couples who wed before the measure passed with 52 percent of the vote. More at>>> >>>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30936298/
